slides.title: Organization and Community Model
slides.originalNotes:
Organization / Community model
PolicyCenter must maintain information about how you organize people and their work. In many cases, you can edit this information within the PolicyCenter administration screens. Users, groups, and producer codes all belong to an organization, which can be the organization of the insurer or an external organization, such as an agency. Organization has groups within it. Users can be assignedto any number of these groups. Producer codes can be assigned to groups or directly to users in an organization.

Users have a list of producer codes allowed for them, eitherexplicitly or through one of the groups that the user is assigned Internal as well as external users, groups, organizations, and permissions can have be assigned producer codes. External users may only have producer codes from their organization assigned to them, but internal users may have any external producer codes explicitly assigned to them.

slides.title: Defining a Producer
slides.originalNotes:
Producer
A producer is a person or organization that has one or more agreements to sell business on behalf of the insurer. A producermay be responsible for many, one, or zero policies. In the insurance industry, producers are typically referred to as agents, brokers, or an internal sales force. The insurer may hold the account directly (insurer contacts the account directly), in which case there is no producer. In some cases, a producer agency has only one associated code. In other cases, an insurer may want to separately track two or more different policy categories assigned to a single producer. In this case, the producer agency
will have multiple codes, and the user must select the appropriate code.

slides.title: Exploring Producer Types
slides.notes: Differentiate between producer of record and producer of service.
slides.narration: Producers can take on various roles, such as the producer of record or producer of service. Initially, the producer of record creates the policy, but over time, a different producer might take over servicing the account. This distinction is important for managing commissions and ensuring the right permissions are in place for policy management.

slides.title: Producer Types in Detail
slides.originalNotes:
Producer types
A producer of record created the policy, may or may not service the account and have limited permissions on the policy and account. For a new policy, the producer of record is the same as producer of service, as shown in the example. If a user decides they want a new agent, then the producer of service changes. The producer providing this new service is the producer of service. The old agent continues to receive a commission for the policy because he was the one that initially brought in the business. This can be viewed on the Policy Info page by typing the effective date of any policy. A producer of service has permission to edit policies for renewal, then becoming the producer of record and receiving a commission.

slides.title: Understanding Producer Codes
slides.originalNotes:
Producer code
Producer codes are used to accurately track which agent or agency is responsible for which policies and accounts. In some cases, a producer agency has only one associated code. In other cases, an insurer may want to separately track two or more different policy categories to a single producer. In this case, the producer agency will have multiple codes, and the user must select the appropriate code. Insurers may think that producer codes follow their organization or group hierarchy, assigning product codes to groups eases administrative duties.

slides.title: Delegating Management with User Admin Role
slides.originalNotes:
Delegate management using User Admin role
Since managing both the internal and external company can become quite complex, management of external producer companies can be delegated to a designated external User Admin. This can be done by assigning the User Admin role to a user within that external organization. That user will have permission to administer Users, Groups, Organizations, and Permissions within the user’s organization, but will not have access to other organizations. Delegating allows a User Admin to build the User, Group, Organization, and Permission sets that represent an external company. Even though you can delegate administration of these external companies, you still have access and complete administrative rights from the Administration tab. The difference between a Supervisor and a User Admin is that a Supervisor has access to the Team screen related to a group whereas the User Admin has the ability to manage Users, Groups, Organizations and Permissions. There is no limit on the number of User Admins in an organization. Roles are discussed later in this lesson.

slides.title: Exploring User Access
slides.originalNotes:
Security in PolicyCenter
Refer to the Roles and Permisslons lesson for more details on Role-Based security. Security in PolicyCenter makes the application flexible, robust, and protects your information. PolicyCenter's default application contains a set of roles that performs policy tasks in most organizations. In order to perform these tasks, a user must be assigned a role with the appropriate permissions. Typically, the Superuser role is granted all permissions in the base configuration and is responsible for granting permissions to other roles. Once the roles are configured, each PolicyCenter user is assigned a specific role that relates to the tasks to be performed. Note: Although Superuser has all permissions in the base configuration, the permissions may change if a customer adds custom permissions. Additionally, Superuser is configured in the base product in the role that would grant permissions to other roles, but a customer can configure any role with the same permissions.

slides.title: External User Access Control
slides.originalNotes:
Producer code security
Access restrictions can be placed through producer code security beyond the permissions associated with the matching producer code, and be applied to an account, policy, or job. For a producer, the producer code security would typically be enabled, but for underwriters or auditors it may disabled, thereby allowing them to work on any policy. You can think of producer codes as an agreement between the producer and the insurer which determines the capabilities of the producer. Attaching permissions to producer codes and attaching the producer codes to users, allows an insurer to:
Further customize what a producer can do
Track the performance of a producer
Tie the producer to a specific organization or region
Users inherit producer codes through their group, producer codes are not explicitly assigned.

slides.title: Summary and Next Steps
slides.originalNotes:
Status field
The status of the matching producer code and the user’s organization must be verified before allowing access through producer code security. Both statuses must be Active or on the list of allowed statuses in the permission handler. Without security handler configuration, full permissions are granted when the status is Active. Permissions are not permitted when the status is anything other than Active, except in the case of Renewals, which is allowed a Limited status. Producer codes are used for account security checks in the absence of any policies or submissions. To configure which permissions are granted when the status of the producer code or agency is other than Active, refer to the Producer Code Permissions lesson or the PolicyCenter Configuration Guide.

User Access

The Groups lists which groups the user belongs to, if the user is a member, whether the user is a Manager, load factor permissions and the load factor within that group. This is useful for activity assignments using assignment rules. Click on a linked group name and open the Groups screen to configure the Groups. Groups are discussed in detail later in this lesson.

Producer Codes from Groups.
The users automatically obtain all of the producer codes assigned to their groups. A user can create collections of permissions as roles and attach them to producer codes, which can then be assigned to users, policies, or accounts. Ijsers for whom Producer Code Security is set to Yes can only use their role permissions against policies that have a matching producer code- Only the producer code permissions that match can be used against a policy, even if the user has a larger set of permissions available through their user roles- Both producer code and user role permissions must match in order for the user to gain access.

Additional Producer Codes:
Users can add producer codes through this option. By default, external producer users can have producer codes from their own organization/groups added. Internal users who have their producer code security turned on can have producer codes from any organization added. However, you can configure the ExternallJserAccess parameter in config.xml to control the level of access for external users.

Default. With Fully Restricted, external users can be assigned to groups only within their organization. Users inherit producer codes from their groups. In addition, external users can be assigned producer codes from their organization.
PROTECTINTERNAL – With Protect Intemal, external users can be assigned to any external group and inherit producer codes from their groups. In addition, external users can be assigned producer codes from any external organization.
ALLOWINTERNAL – With Allow Internal, external users can be assigned to any group, internal or extemal. Users inherit producer codes from their groups. In addition, external users can be assigned producer codes frominternal or extemal organizations.

This parameter can be changed as needed to increase access to groups and producer codes. However, be aware that limiting access requires that all users, groups, and producer codes are reviewed to ensure that they conform to a more restrictive parameter setting.
